description: All I can say is that Bob's is the best place ever. It's so cheap, and sooooo yummy. A great place to end the night after all the bars close...and then to start the next morning too.
author: cait b.

description: Got em fresh out of the fryer. I am in love with the donut crumb covered donut. It's like delish covered with more delish. We tried the maple glazed custard filled, the choco glazed, the cinnamon sugar, and the aforesaid crumb covered donut. Fabulous! Plus they had orange glazed ones special for halloween. Cute!
author: Jennifer C.

description: The donuts here are undeniably delicious, but it's the service and attitude that makes them, ahem, difficult to swallow.  I live in the neighborhood and come (correction, came) here with some regularity.  Whether it is a younger worker or the owner, they have an attitude with certain customers -- they seem to love the haole customers but not their own.  The last time I came, I wanted to buy a chocolate sprinkled donut for my 3 year old daughter (who was well behaved and excited to be getting a treat) -- the owner purposefully picked one which only had a few sprinkles deep in the case when they had many other donuts with lots of sprinkles.  When I pointed this out, she said she took the one closest to her (not true), then tried to force me to buy the sparsely sprinkled donut by accusing me of touching it (I only touched the wrapper).  I then asked for napkins (3 year old), and they gave me a single napkin, forcing me to have to ask for more. I don't get it -- the donut she tried to force me to buy must have cost her 5 cents to make -- why upset a customer for life?  Then I heard her complaining to the other haole customers about us on my way out.  My 3 year old was traumatized and needless to say, we won't be coming back.  So, if you are haole, I'm sure the donuts and experience will remain tasty; if you are not -- be forewarned.
author: Brian H.

description: So disappointed to find out they were all out of apple fritters at the time. Luckily all of their other donuts were fresh out of the fryer. I got a delicious crumb donut and some cinnamon twisty glaze thing which was also amazing. Can't wait to go back and get the apple fritter!
author: Thomas D.

description: Whats the big deal about this place? I was expecting an out of body experience after reading these reviews. What I got was a donut. A normal donut that I can get anywhere. The lady who worked there was super nice, though.
author: Tim M.

description:
SO FUCKING GOOD. THIS PLACE WILL TURN ME INTO A WHALE.

I've had the regular maple glazed donut several times and each time is as orgasmic as the last. Also had the maple glazed filled with custard which was mind bogglingly good as well. i cannot wait to get drunk this weekend and buy one of the HUGE donuts they make.

I ate one last week and threw up an hour later from something completely unrelated (I was helping my drunk friend who was throwing up and my weak gag reflex kicked in, leading to my throw up) but it was the best vomit of my life because it tasted like maple glaze.
author: K C.

description: $2.50 for 2 large pastries is a pretty amazing deal in this city. I couldn't resist devouring my first donut on the walk home. I told myself that I would save my apple fritter for tomorrow, but I couldn't help but take a nibble, which turned into several gigantic bites. The apple fritter is amazing.. it feels like a thousand layers of solidified grease, and I'm sure it's a million calories, but it's worth it occasionally. It's not too sweet. Being in this place feels like you stepped back into the 50's, and there are some interesting characters hanging around late at night. 75 cent coffee? I haven't seen that since I was a kid... although I'm doubtful about the quality. The diner-esque carafes looked like they'd been sitting for a while.
author: Jade S.

description:
Seriously, one of the best donuts I've ever had. Especially good during late nights when their donuts are freshly made. 

I swear I hear people talking about Bob's Donuts even outside of CA, but it could just all be in my head.
author: Cyndi L.

description: yes it's a 7x7, but not so unique.  for example if you get a fritter fresh out the fryer at kingpin, or a maple buttermilk at donut wheel, it's amazing.  pretty much timing is everything, and asking for the freshest is the smartest way to go.  buttermilks are perfect when they have the crisp outer edge with sugary glaze and soft moist inner.  what we really need is something like a creme brulee donut from donut planet NYC.  if you're planning a midnight donut, i think they usually come out a little earlier than that for the late night rush.
author: Rob C.

description: BEST APPLE FRITTER EVER! Dense, sugary, deliciousness. 'Nuf said.
author: Natalie N.

description:
This place is the king of all donuts. They stay open super late, they're always making freshies, and it never takes more than 5 minutes to get what you need. Being the drunken stoner that I am, I can say from a great deal of personal experience that this place serves some of the best munchies in town. I'm disappointed by a lot of donut shops' chocolate, but this place somehow got the formula just right. Delicious.

There are some really cool people who work here, too. One youngish asian lady is hillarious. My friend and I were trying to hit on a couple Japanese girls in there one night. The next time the lady behind the counter saw us she remembered and starting teasing us. It was a classic donut-related moment.

I recommend the donut holes, if you're into that kind of thing.
author: Adam R.

description:
How come every time I want donuts and I eat donuts I eat until I am satisfied and then till I am too full and so on until I get sick and upset? 
This place would be allright with a disclaimer...
author: Cameron Scott C.

description: delicious hole in a wall donuts shop, IM THERE!!!
author: Tess C.

description: Apple fritters were amazing, especially when it's warm. We went there two days in a row and found out that they have more warm items around 2am...well worth standing in line and staying up that late.
author: Jo Y.

description:
I've decided to give up on the whole "skinny" thing.  Clearly, I am no longer meant to be a waif.  What this means:  no more size 6 dresses, no more looking like a 21 year-old in a bathing suit, and _lots_  of food - including donuts. 
After a hearty meal at Victor's Pizza, my crew decided to top it all off with some deep-fried doughy goodness. 
My first impression wasn't so hot.  A homeless guy tried to help my 
two-year-old up onto a stool.  Um, "No thanks, I've got her!" I know she's adorable and that her outfit was kinda strange - fake fur hoodie, pink leggings,  and a big chain necklace (she insisted on dressing herself).  But,  still - WTF? Don't touch my baby, dude!!!
The donuts almost made up for the initial creepiness.  The kids had chocolate-coated cake donuts and I had a raspberry-filled, chocolate-covered wonder of a treat.  I think our friend Olivia went for the maple.  We washed down the sweet fried deliciousness with tiny cartons of milk. 
Now, If i I could just wash away the memory of skeezie reaching for my kid!
author: Kati K.

description: bob' s the biznezz! 24 hour fresh donuts!!!!! hell yeah.
author: Ashley H.

description:
I'm gonna meditate long and hard on this.  

I've strolled past Bob's donuts a million times before but had never aspired, or even thought, to walk in.  Donuts are truly my favorite snack. To enjoy them, well, that was once a carefree snacking sensation requiring only the raw instinct to masticate with whimsy.  Once you reach this age and metabolism, enjoying deep fried dough dumplings, now much more rare indeed, takes on a heavier air of consequence and requires deliberate musing, brooding and chin stroking.  The threat of ingesting meaningless carbs, fat and calories poses only secondary concern.  More importantly, ugly premonitions of the slow, painful, gastrointestinal mini-implosion to come take flight in the mind's eye, for donuts - those irresistible little puffs of sweet dough, some airy and light, others dense and cakey - which come in an almost endless array of flavors, styles, shapes and colors, are at once the most lethal poison and the perfect pastry and thus embody true evil.   

So when my compadre and I recently revived our ancient ritual quest for the perfect donut, Bob's was one of our first destinations.  We tried Happy donut...fair.  We tried Rolling Pin...fair to middling.  We tried All Star...less than fair (pubic hair on donut).  And then we remembered Bob's.  The Bob's that we had both sauntered past countless times without a second glance.  

As you step inside, you step back in time and can hardly believe your eyes or that you've neglected this place for so long: old fashioned (formica) counter service with little (vinyl) stools, a clunky TV with a faded screen and rabbit ears, an old Triple Play pinball machine in the back corner, walls covered with near-psychedelic artistry, a grizzled bum sucking down black coffee, a friendly talkative chinese lady behind the counter serving your heart's desire from out of the racks in the window while yabbering without pause.  

Hush now woman.  You have entered the sacred ground of the donut temple.  You are the monk.  In an instant, words become meaningless.  To meditate on a donut is mentally backbreaking work until you find yourself gazing face to face into the enlightenment of a jelly crossed buttermilk.  Allow your burdensome worries to just (apple) fritter away, as if ethereal gasses catching a ride on the eastern winds.  Embrace the ecstasy of donut nirvana.  There are no painful consequences in the donut temple, only vinyl, formica, and pure sublime deeply fried beauty.
author: Rick H.

description:
we've been having potluck lunches here at work every day since December &  people have been bringing in all kinds of delicious crap including donuts, cookies, cake, high sugar content you name it.

ive been snorting sugar like a fiend.

last saturday was girls night at amelie on polk and i started off the evening with a hot donut from bob's.  it was amazing.  melty and soft like a cloud of heaven.

the rest of the night was spent restlessly making fake conversation with people while all i could think about was more donuts.  so that's how i made two trips to bob's in less than 3 hours.

if you can, get em hot, that's my sugar wisdom for ya.
author: Josie M.

description: It's the old, hole in the wall places that have been around forever that are the best.  Bob's is a prime example of this.  Buttermilk donuts fresh out of the fryer and glazed right in front of you.......need I say more?  I walk to Russian Hill for my guilty pleasure at least once a week.
author: Nicole W.

description: 305 reviews for a donut shop on Polk, do I really need to say anything else about this place?
author: Luis M.

description:
I ate an entire chocolate glazed donut, an entire chocolate glazed donut with jam, part of an apple bread pudding pie type thing and tried a couple bites of a sugar donut.  So you can't say I didn't try to like this place.  I even had the coffee.  I can't say I was impressed.  Which is weird because all signs pointed to deliciousness.  Why?  Because we were hungry.  We wanted donuts.  Theirs smelled really good.  The weather was nice.  We found parking immediately.  And everyone and their mama loves this place.  But you know, friends, I gotta say, it wasn't all that.

My buddy and I had been stressed out for two weeks straight, so on a beautiful Sunday afternoon after a day of running errands, we had to call an Emergency Donut Break.  I tell her that there's this donut place called Bob's in the Russian Nob area that's supposed to serve some bad ass donuts and pastries.  The donuts and pastries came.  We munched on the donuts.  They were fine.  Not good, not bad, just fine.  The coffee was okay.  The apple bread pudding pie concoction was downright nasty.  All in all, a pretty mediocre experience.  I looked at the Yelp sticker displayed proudly on their pastry case, looked at my friend and just went, "I don't get it."  She looked back at me and goes, "I don't get it either."  Pretty much, if this place wasn't open so late at night to catch all the hungry drunks and stoners with a bad case of the munchies, they probably would not have much of a selling point.  

Final verdict?  I think you have to be drunk or stoned or both to really enjoy this place.  Totally sober on a Sunday afternoon?  Not so much.
author: Diana Y.

description:
i know bob of bobs. he really isnt a bob, but bob seemed like a good name for a big donut munching dood. been a customer since my forced volunteerism days at the youth center nearby.

i still get a couple dozens every monday morning for my work crew and customers. 

BEST APPLE FRITTER. BEST GLAZED.  go during the night. i swear they make them better at night for all the stoners and drunks. SOOO many nights going by after clubbing. warning fresh hot donuts will burn your mouth.
author: Euge L.

description: Bob's Donuts is a gloriously gratifying gastronomical delight not to be missed or dismissed.
author: Charlie B.

description: I was waiting for the #19 bus and the place just smelled delicious! I walked in and they had something just out of the oven. No idea what it was but it was covered in maple syrup and I couldn't believe how delicious it was! I'm REALLY not a sugar fan (give me potato chips any day) but I'll be coming back to this place! To top it off, the price was $1.10. In a city where many things are overpriced, I got a delicious treat for an amazing price!
author: Dana C.

description: I didn't think it was possible to make fried dough taste any better, but then I went to Bob's. Ask for the freshly made ones, they are absolutely worth it, even if you don't get your favorite. The buttermilk donut is everything life should be. The people who work here are also extremely nice, which I've always found to be kind of rare in donut shops. And they even have the requisite depressed old people sitting at the counter chugging back drip coffee. Every neighborhood should have one of these (can they take over Happy Donuts?).
author: Maria D.

description: We went at 4 pm on a weekday so there were no lines or seedy characters outside. The woman who served us was very nice and helped us choose a big box of goodies. Then she threw in some free donut holes.  They did not appear to have a big selection of raised donuts only cake ones so we got chocolate croissants, apple fritter, almond Danish, and long johns.  They did not have any bread or bagels. All so far have been delish!
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
holy crap i love bobs.

especially when they make their donuts fresh at like 2:00am.  

the chocolate sprinkle and the crumb are my FAVE.

for extra special occasions, get a HUGE $12.00 donut the size of a plate.  (FYI, must order in advance, but they will make ANY kind of donut).
author: Jasmine S.

description: I will not eat apple fritters anywhere else other than Bob's. They're amorphous blobs of fried heaven. I think the lady who works there is sweet on me because every time I order one she spends a little extra time picking out the gnarliest, most heavily glazed one in the pile. She's either sweet on me or she's trying to kill me. Either way, god bless her. The jelly filled are pretty amazing too although they're more like two donuts bound together by jelly. Don't eat more than one in a sitting or you'll end up on a rooftop thinking you can fly.
author: Josua P.

description: Everything Krispy Kremes are supposed to be but aren't. Where else can you better satisfy a craving for sweets in the wee hours of the morning? This place is so amazing, you won't mind dealing with the strung-out hustlers littering Polk Street in order to score an apple fritter hot from the oven. Anything with apples must be good for you, right?
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Um...YUM YUM. Every time I'm in the area (my friend lives on Polk), I insist on going to Bob's for a donut. She usually resists (she's much more disciplined than I am!) but sometimes she caves and we leave with our paper bags of donut goodness.  

Missing one star because I think they could do with a better seating area. But I dont blame them because they have to deal with a lot of weirdos.

I love the crumb cake donuts, the maple ones, the buttermilk ones. The apple bread pudding thing was so-so. 

Friendly service, open 24 hours, hot, sweet, greasy scrumptiousness just when you need it.
author: Tara S.

description:
What's the fuss?    I base this review on more than just the donuts.
I had (parts of) a buttermilk donut (with raspberry topping) and an apple fritter.  The donuts are traditional and very, very good.  
Very average coffee and not hot.  An old shop so no rest room for clients.  Good coffee and a rest room next door at Royal Ground Coffee.
A very good neighborhood donut joint if you are in the area, but not a destination.  Certainly not a Best of the Bay.
author: Bob M.

description: Ok, to be honest, I don't know that I need to go here again at midnight. fresh donuts were SO GOOD, but the hot grease was not a friendly reminder of what I was eating. If you wait til morning, the grease is all soaked in and invisible!  tell me lies, sweet little lies.
author: Liz S.

description: I got so absorbed in Bob's cinnamon crumb donut the other day that I nearly got run over by a car. I made the mistake of trying to eat and walk at the same time.
author: Megan W.

description:
wonderful.... just wonderful...

i wish you guys delivered...

people, people.... u don't know donut, till you have tried this place...

it's so good... i use a fork and knife...
author: Mike K.

description: Seriously?  I know the best time to get the donuts are after 11pm since they start baking fresh donuts around 9... but they are even amazing half a day old!!  Bob's Donuts are really really addicting!!  They always have a great variety and since they are open 24 hours.. well you know!!  One of my favorite places in San Francisco!!  Too bad I can't eat these donuts for every course!
author: Samantha S.

description: This is the best donut shop in the city! They really know their donuts, and at just the right magical time of night, you can taste their yummy donuts fresh out of the oven and dripping with that liquid sugar goodness.
author: Betty B.

description: I would convert to obesity if it meant I could constantly mainline Bob's donuts.  Maple anything--bars, regulars, old fashioned's....it would be a good, though gouty, life.
author: Shannon V.

description: Forget Krispy Kreme, those in the know visit Bob's for the real deal. Go after the bars close - that's when the donuts are piping hot - if they have the munchie special, I'd recommend that!
author: Nish N.

description:
#80 on the "big eat sf" list - apple fritter

i'm confused. it was good, but why so special for this list? it's just what you'd expect...maybe cuz we didn't get a fresh one?
author: S V.

description: Maple Buttermilk Bars. Call ahead and find out when they are coming out of the vat. Then call me with your heartfelt thanks.
author: patrick g.

description: Feenin for donuts, something to drink, or just need someplace to sober your ass up then BOBS is the place to be. Did this girl right before me say something about krispy kreme? Whimpy Kreme and their little puny, over sugared donuts aint got nothing on BOBS.  Its not even close.  "Minh Masta Bake" bakes the donuts fresh with a "special kind of dough" as BOB would say. Honestly, Ive never tasted anything better. Their french crawlers are off the heezy.... their apple fritters, just plain stupid dumb. Oh yea, and if the crazy folks on polk street start bothering you just tell bob about it. Hed be happy to kick the shit outta them for you. Ive seen him in action. Now thats some full service for ya.
author: Winston K.

description: I am pretty sure this place is open 24 hours. Can we say dangerous. ....A certain friend of mine loves this place so much she keeps the bag so she can smell it.
author: Stacy H.

description: Apple fritters , especially when still warm are a revelation.  Their regular donuts and pastries are also worth taking into the office or a friends party to become an instant hero.
author: MJ C.

description: Great place for fresh donuts any time of the day.  They're open 24/7!  You can't go wrong with the wide selection.  If you go there around 10pm or 11pm,  there will be fresh hot donuts that will have you coming back for ages.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Seriously, this is one of those famous SF institutions that the locals love, but the dough here is actually very tasty.  Especially the apple fritters..they're just greasy enough and perfectly sugary frosted.  I've tied them sober and drunk and they tasted great on both occasions.  Think that's the ultimate test, heehee.
author: Joyhan S.

description: This place is inSANE. It beat out Tim Hortons hands down, and I'm Canadian so that is sayin' something. I didn't even think I liked cake donuts until I ate this one, and it was the best tasting thing I've eaten in YEARS (it was warm, btw, which makes a difference).
author: Jen D.

description: Not much to say that hasn't been said about how amazing these donuts are.  If you can deal with the humiliation of eating donuts in your PJs while cool people are out clubbing down the street, I recommend going at 11:30pm-ish, when the donuts are fresh.  They taste totally different hot and just out of the oven and by different I mean even better than they taste normally, if that's possible.  My favs are the old-fashioned, crumb and buttermilk.  Beware--these things are SWEET so if you don't like sweet things, I'd recommend you go elsewhere.
author: Kristin P.

description: This place is a neighborhood gem. BEST to go here late night when the donuts are still hot from the fryer. Getting hungry just thinking about it. Try the giant donut challenge if you dare.
author: David C.

description:
This is a real old-fashioned donut hole. I love it! They make the best cheese danish in the city. The people who work here are very friendly. It's a real Polk Street institution. Hang out for a while and you get a good sampling of the neighborhood characters.

I would recommend avoiding the big sheet cake looking thing with the apples on the top. Some people like it, but it's like eating a lead brick. Otherwise, I've never been disappointed.
author: Scotia W.

description: My favorite: the regular glaze donut. It's what a donut should taste like. The moment you break it apart and see it's doughy, soft texture, that's when you know it's going to be amazing. Nuke it for a few seconds, down it with milk and you've got a tasty treat - breakfast, lunch and dinner.
author: Victor B.

description:
where else can i go to get crunchy, crusty, cakey old fashions after boozing it up at the hemlock and bigfoot in the wee hours of the morning?

bob's donuts. that's right.
author: May T.

description: Thank you, thank you, thank you. For saving my butt this past weekend. Not only did your fried doughy treats taste soooo good at 3am, the remaining ones got me out of jail the next morning when I served one to my gf with coffee.
author: Robbie G.

description: Best time for Bob's is after 11pm when they start frying the doughnuts. You can sit down at the counter and watch for a while, and they'll sell you a freshly fried and dipped one. I like the plain old fashioned but the chocolate old fashioned are also amazing when just recently cooked. Their Apple Pandowdy, a brick-sized slab of day old doughnuts held together with gooey apples, is carbo heaven. When I was a waitress I used to eat two or three a week and I never got tired. Also a great place for people watching. This place is a neighborhood staple and has delicious jelly doughnuts made with real, good quality jelly.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Bob's Donuts and I have an understanding. Whenever I stop by during the late evenings, warm, fresh donuts are on a metal tray waiting for me. The smell of the newly deep fried dough dipped in chocolate agrees with me very much. I don't know whether to eat them or make love to them.
author: Jordan A.

description: Bob's is an Oasis for a wandering, sugar-starved city dweller.  Prices are cheap, service is friendly, and people-watching is always fun as it is an ecclectic mix of Polk-area Nob Hillers and homeless shelter-seekers.  Tip: Go later at night, around 10 PM and you can get your own sugar-dripping treat hot out of the donut machines.  Or go early in the AM for some of the best donut holes this side of Dunkin Donuts.  And it is reassuring that they do not serve burgers or fish tacos or any other non-donut related goods.  Whether it is the smell of fresh donutz or the visions of sweetness in the window as you walk by, Bob's will surely pry your money from your wallet again...and again...and again.
author: Lucas M.

description: This is the only place to get the classic glazed donut. Little fried pillows of dough that melt inside your mouth. This is the best, not the sickeningly sweet things you get at Krispy Kreme, including one right out of the hot oil. Think Snuffles, the cartoon dog who would hug himself, levitate into mid-air and then slowly return to earth as he concluded his orgasmic eating frenzy.
author: Arlene C.

description:
can i just tell you that Bob makes all things better?
having a shitty day? go to bob's.
drunk and desperately in need of food? head on over to bob's.
just gave the most embarrassing karaoke performance ever at encore? pssh... wipe those feelings away with bob's.
made out with your best friend.... both of them? yeaaa.... you know the drill.

the glazed donut, esp when it's still warm, is freaking orgasmic. and the crumb donut and the cinsugar donut are both pretty freaking fabulous themselves. 

i think i'm going to give up all my other men and give my devotion entirely to bob... who has been and will always be wayyy more than simply satisfactory.
author: rachel b.

description: I had always found Nob Hill to be a bland neighborhood, lacking in character and main attractions. This was before I experienced Bob's Donut Shop. I will now forever be jealous of my co-workers on the hill. We passed by late at night and the smell lured us in. As we entered, a fresh batch of donut holes was coming out of the deep fryer. If that wasn't enough to make you salivate, we then witnessed the glazing process. Oh good lord, just dripping in sugary hot glaze. I was torn on what to order since everything looked amazing but I had to go for the fresh donut holes. At 15 cents a piece, I should have ordered a hundred but I held back and only had a handful. What a stupid stupid mistake...
author: Susan L.

description: Bob's Donuts. I love you. You always have freshly made donuts, you're open 24 hours, and you have giant cake-sized donuts. I know that you're known for your apple fritter, unfortunately I just don't typically eat them, but some day...I will try yours. Because it's yours and I don't think you could make anything that wouldn't be delicious.
author: Tiff L.

description: Possibly the best donut I have ever had!!!  After asking a friend for the best bakery in town, this is where I landed!  Great call Eduardo:)...the donut was super fresh as the coffee was served with a smile...life is good, especially when it involves a little sugar;)
author: Brooke C.

description: Even though the lady behind the counter was super sweet, my apple fritter (which I'd been looking forward to all night due to Yelp reviews) was just "okay." I was disappointed with the lack of apple chunks and the dry texture. I think the key to having the best Bob's experience is to drop by just when the donuts are coming out of the fryer. I'm sure once I try a fresh one, my rating will go up. But until then...three stars.
author: Nathalie L.

description: These rat-bastards make a point of piping all that sweet, warm, doughnuty air out into the dank environs of Polk Street at 3am, just as most of us are stumbling home from a night of avoiding the beautiful people on Russian Hill.  When Amanda lived on Nob Hill, I usually parked near Ruth's Chris, so I had to buy some donuts at Bob's and tear into them so my olfactory senses would not notice the steak smell further along and order me to break into Ruth's Chris and loot the place.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Note that many of the other reviewers mention being drunk or getting over a hangover when they visit this place.  Most sugar food tastes good then.  Try going sober.  
I have had the pecan bun, the apple turnover, and the bear claw.  I would not recommend any of them.  The buns were dry and stingy on the sugar.  The apple turnovers had maybe 2 pieces of apple, and again, were very dry.  The bear claw was sub-par- they've got the more bitter than tasty kind of almond paste inside.  
Qualification: I've only stopped by here in the afternoons when things aren't as fresh...but pastries are either moist or they're not.  Since I'm always waiting at the bus stop outside I'll give the regular donuts reviewed by others a try, and perhaps then will have to edit my review...till then.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE:
Okay, the sugar twist is pretty good, and has a nice cinnamon dusting.
Also, the apple fritter is reasonably good.  
One more star.
author: CAKE E.

description: The place was packed at 9:30pm with more people eating donuts than in some of the restaurants on the block. We were hunting for dinner so we came back in the morning for breakfast and WOW D-Lish-us! So fresh and yummy! I had one with some Cinnamon crumbles on it and my friend had a cinnamon roll. Even the coffee was good. You will not be disappointed.
author: Tanya C.

description: Every time I'm in the mood for the giant donut, they don't have it. And every time I'm walking past without enough time to stop in, there's the elusive giant donut. But that's ok, they have really good pastries and the blueberry cobbler is my all time favorite.
author: Ryan H.

description: Great old school, home fried doughnuts and fritters.  Delicious streudels and cookies too - best place in the City - open 24/7.
author: R F.

description:
Best Donuts in the city HAND'S HELLA DOWN!!!!!

We used to live around the corner and would go there around midnight right when the glazed would come out. You have to time it right you know..... if you go in the afternoon or mid-evening, you'll get the ones that have been sitting out for a while....not worth it in my opinion. But now they do glazed around 1a.m. Chocolate and other goodies around 2a.m. The Red Devil crowd can sometimes be annoying....but they don't stay long because they are too drunk and stupid to know where they are. There's even a pinball machine and you can watch random cable on their little tv when sitting at the counter. Sadly my boyfriend and I had to limit our Bob's journey's because eating donuts every night, no matter how good they are makes you really fat. Which is why if you check out some of my other reviews, I've hired a personal trainer to take off the Bob's. But there is no hating here.....I've just learned to moderate my relationship with Bob.
author: K B.

description: Ahh, I've been craving their donuts FOREVER! Since the very first time I had their donuts I've been dreaming about eating more!! This place is just too far for me to keep coming back often.  This place probably has the best crumb donuts. The crumb donuts are big, moist, fluffy and ooooh soo freakin delish! The apple fritter or something is pretty good too. I wish it had more of an apple taste though. But nonetheless, it was yummy! I also tried the bread pudding which was topped with apples...that was sooo good. Their bread pudding is very unique..haven't had a bread pudding like this anywhere else.  I had the chocolate and glazed cruellers too and those were so moist and yummy! Of course the next time i come back here I definitely wanna get here early to get some fresh donuts. We got to the donut shop around 9pm or something so most of the donuts were gone. Can't wait for my next visit.
author: Sylvia H.

description: Sweet tooth at 2am?  Go to Bob's Donuts on Polk and get the GIANT chocolate glazed donut.  Warning--do NOT try to finish this by yourself =P.  Definitely meant to be shared given it's the size of a mini tire.  They make em fresh every night--I think around 1am?  Hits the 2am sweet spot just like the super burrito heats the savory spot.
author: Saha N.

description:
So I love my fancy French bakeries, but I also love a good American style donut place (Ok, I just love anything fattening), especially when it is of such classic quality like Bob's.  

I love the raspberry jelly-filled, old fashioned maple, and of course the apple fritter.  And the owners and staff are local and very nice!
author: t l.

description: It must have been after midnight, with my wife, both tipsy.  We entered Bob's as the dounuts were being fried (by hand, not like the Krap at Krispy Kreme) and covered in chocolate.  They were hot, and to this day Bob's is my favorite.   For some reason their donuts always taste better and did I mention that they are open, after midnight, when you are tipsy and looking to score some hot donuts?
author: George S.

description: I'm hesitant to share this little tidbit.  Bob's Donuts simply cannot be beat.  Doesn't matter when you go, the donuts are always good...worth rock-paper-scissoring over who has to get up and go buy donuts on Sunday morning.
author: Kristen N.

description: Best donuts in town.  To the naysayers, give it another chance.  This place has been around for a long time.  I don't know who the "crabby lady" is, but I know the folks that own and run the place and they are far from crabby.  They are all very personable and know how to make their donuts.  Maybe you caught them on an off-night...it happens.
author: Hodie K.

description: Last saturday night at 1am, and after too many drinks, I stumbled upon Bob's. Normally, I would hit up a slice, but the delicious aroma of donuts on the street was too strong to ignore. I quickly ate two glazed donuts and stood mesmerized by the guy making donuts the old fashioned way with no fancy machines, just a large fryer. The next day, I weighed 4 pounds more than normal, but i couldn't stop thinking about the donuts. Somehow, I think my brain was completely re-wired after Bob's. I highly recommend trying Bob's late night, as I did, because then you won't feel as guilty.
author: Josiah H.

description:
oh
my 
gawd

fresh, hot,  crazy good donuts at 2am?! deadly.

and the nicest staff to boot

i was there with a 'regular' who could barely resist screaming upon seeing the hot donuts. if you ever do running into a customer screaming with joy, say hi, Matt is quite friendly
author: tara s.

description: open late, the bigass donut they make on friday nights are so cool! =)
author: Lisa N.

description:
mmm apple fritters......

no seriously this place is always open.. 
so when i get a craving at an obscure time I take a walk over to Bob's
And those massive ass donuts they make.. man those things last you for a week (or a day depending or your intake)

Bob's is pretty sweet.. 
If my girlfriend is sad or upset, I go there and get a selection.
And that woman talks to you forever, pretty funny to listen to her comical view on life..

Go get some.... NOW!!
author: Dave L.

description: Best Dougnuts i ever tasted. Nice and fresh every time a i go there. Great Counter service and the pricing is just right.  I could go every day to this place. but i have to watch my calories and my blood sugar.
author: steve a.

description: When it comes to describing the perfection of Bob's Donuts, my vocabulary lacks sufficient cabability...so I think I'll keep it short and sweet (pun intended) and in the words of a 7 year old boy who rolled out of Bob's one morning still licking his fingers: "Mom, that was the best donut I have ever had".  I didn't want to let him know that, considering the fact that his family looked to be tourists, there was a distinct possibility that his donut might retain that best ever status quo indefinitely. I almost pitied him.
author: julia r.

description: People that rave about hot Krispy Kreme donuts have never had a hot, fresh from the vat donut from Bob's after the bars close. It's absolutely to die for. And I would also like to suggest that fried donuts are the best way to soak up all that alcohol you've just consumed...helping to alleviate those inevitable hangover symptoms that will materialize when you wake up!
author: Suepattra M.

description: Donut's at 1am, freshy fried and coated with sugary glaze. The perfect spot for drunk munchies. Bring your peeps and get an extra large donut that is the size of a small pizza. Everyone can take a bite at the same time. What a bonding experience!
author: Karen C.

description:
someone recommended the apple fritters, and i would say that's the best one there.  it was in the afternoon, so they werent as fresh as should be, but the apple friitter still shined through.

i will go back to try a more fresh version of the custard filled maple and chocolate.
author: I Be E.

description: OMG! Is it the show or the donuts I like best here? The buttermilk bars at 2 am are the best! The club noise was still ringing in my ears so I missed most of what was said but I got an eye full of how them buggars are made. Somewhere in the back of my inebriated mind Huell Howser was asking, "Luis get a shot of those old fashions gettin' glazed."  Oh, I just looked down at my dikdo while writing this...THANKS A LOT BOB!
author: JayChan H.

description: Out of town visitor here staying at Holiday Inn, accidentally saw this place while walking on Polk.  We went back there 3 nights in a row.  Love this little place.
author: Nikko V.

description: A friend dragged me to Bob's at like 3 am.  I was exhausted and wanted to go home, skeptical of the power of these exalted donuts.  I don't even like donuts, especially Krispy Kremes that kill you with sugar.  Anyways, he said that we had to have the GIANT donut so we split it 3 ways.  Wow! I was actually impressed at the moist flakiness of this donut.  I think that size does matter - it more like a cake, hence not sure how the normal size donuts taste.  Ok, I'll stop here because the word donut is starting to sound funny to me from saying it so many times.
author: Sunny C.

description: Amazing donuts! I can't wait to have a complete breakdown of will power so I can buy a giant glazed! I also hope that in my life time Bob's does not succumb to the Polk Street Smug Washers ;-)
author: Matt C.

description:
I definitely recommend this place. I ordered 10 donuts, I only paid 8.50 dollars and donuts were delicious.
 Also the woman cashier is friendly.
author: Cloclo R.

description: San Francisco's last remaining donut shop.  Come try em before they get bought out!  I'm a something of a donut expert.  I could tell you all about the history, the mixes in use today, the optimal fry technique, etc.  But the existing reviews tell all you need to know.  These are good, honest doughnuts.
author: Morey S.

description: I was excited to go to Bob's after finding it on SFGate's best of list and seeing the great Yelp reviews but I was a little let down when I arrived. I was told there were great apple fritters but I didn't see any and there weren't signs to say what you were looking at or what they had behind the counter. I didn't want to be the idiot who asks for something they don't sell so I stuck with what I saw and could identify -- glazed twist and a croissant. Aside from it being too much food, it was a delicious breakfast.
author: Andrew B.

description: I randomly came across Bob's today after bringing my car to the dealership.  To my surprise, I ended up having the best old-fashioned glazed donut I ever had.  And the sugar donut was really tasty as well.  The donuts were also very reasonably priced.  I will be sure to make it out to Bob's whenever I'm in the area, and recommend you do too.
author: Zachary K.

description: From reading the reviews, it appears that I came at the wrong time. The apple fritter was nonetheless very good, albeit a little burnt. Will come back sometime when they are fresh.
author: Mark A.

description: So SO good on a late Saturday night! The Giant twist is the BEST!
author: Darcy M.

description: Bob's, sweet Bob's... How I love thee. Hot donuts if you're there late (and how could you NOT be there late), the coffee is always scaldingly hot, the people watching is unparalleled, and the employees are generally awesome! My favorite is the maple frosted french donut, but the best thing you can do is to ask what's hot. And just because it needs to be mentioned: giant donuts on the weekend!
author: katharine s.

description: Best donuts in SF!! My old church use to be in this neighborhood, so I use to stop by here every Sunday! I would always get the apple fritter! This thing is huge! Crunchy and sweet on the outside and soft, gooey with bits of apples and cinnaminon on the inside! I haven't been there for years until recently. I work only 3 blocks away now. It's still the same old apple fritter! Oh man.. it brought back memories. REALLY bad... since I walk by here everyday during lunch. Yikes!!
author: Denise L.

description: This place is open twenty four hours, and they have fresh donuts at 1:30 which is coincidentally when I tend to leave Bigfoot just up the street. Need I say more?
author: Cathy T.

description:
My experience:
It was an extra fat night,
Drinks at Medjool, Quesidilla at El Farralito,  top off the night with some tumbs and Bob's doughnuts.  Got there just before 2am, of course there is a line outside.  Were standing outside staring at the huge array of doughnuts and pastries all strategically planted in the street facing window.  There is a a girl clerk and an older Asian guy right behind her making the doughnuts.  Seeing them drizzle glaze over fresh doughnuts is an awesome mouthwatering sight.  On the other hand, seeing the guy drop 2 cinder block sized bricks of Lard into the fryer is exactly what I don't want to see.  That did not stop me from getting a crumb doughnut.  It was amazing, Super Soft and delicious, I'm not sure if its really all that much better than any other fresh made doughnut, but at 2 am its fresh and delicious, and you don't have to wake up at 4am to get a fresh one at a normal doughnut place with all the other old geezers.
author: Robert S.

description: This place by far has the best donuts EVER. My husband and I were craving donuts at 2 in the morning and walked over to Bob's.. AMAZINGGG.. I think they make their donuts fresh from 10pm-6am ish... Everything's delicious there. You should definitely try their apple fritter when it's fresh.  But everything there tastes great. Their prices range from $0.80 (for a normal cake donut) to $2.50 (for a piece of pie). Definitely 5 Stars!
author: Jess K.

description: I am very happy to have moved AWAY from Bob's Donuts because the temptation was to strong to resist. Would be walking home from a bar with the boyfriend, and as we neared Bob's we'd always start trying to convince ourselves that we didn't NEED a donut. Moments later, we'd continue our walk home, donuts in hand.
author: Lauren G.

description: I always feel really sorry for the nice girl behind the counter that has to deal with all us inebriated folks at 2 in the morning, but I sure am grateful she's there. Nothing better than a cake donut and few chocolate glazed ones to lull me into a sugar-induced slumber
author: Zoe W.

description: It's a shame that the people who work here are very not San Franciscan. The donuts are great, but the people are rude and unpleasant.
author: Jessie J.

description: I had the pleasure of having one of these fried nuggets of goodness the same day I had a dynamo donut.  It wasn't the first time I had tried either, but starting my day with a Dynamo donut and ending my night with a Bob's donut really allowed me to compare and contrast.  I love them both, but I have to say the simple, 85 cent, maple-glazed donut I had at Bob's was every bit as good, if not better, than the $2 vanilla bean donut I had at Dynamo.  This place is really a gem.  A warm Bob's donut with a carton of milk is about as good as it gets.
author: Michelle A.

description: I think the main attraction about this place is that it's open 24 hours - definitely a plus.  The donuts aren't that special - I'd take the apple fritter from Starbucks any day (seriously) or even a trip to Safeway.  That being said, the donuts are good.  Are donuts ever not good?
author: Cathy L.

description: The apple fritters are the bomb and very reasonably priced.  And they package everything up in the most darling pink boxes.  I imagine the Beaver's mom would have shopped here if she lived in San Francisco.
author: Amy Z.

description: Holy crap, BEST donuts you will ever find. I come from a family of cops, its in my genes to know.
author: Eddie M.

description: Best doughnuts I've ever had. So good, I brought 6 to southern California via southwest for my family to try. It's THAT good! I recommend the crumb and old fashioned, but ony get them when they're fresh!
author: Josh E.

description:
Such wonderful folks, they are. I suggested Bob's to a drunk group of wedding partiers, including the bride and groom, at 3AM after a raucous night of partying. Someone casually mentioned that the couple had gotten married, and the counter lady handed the newlyweds a gigantic glazed donut on the house. I remember this every time I'm there and leave them a nice tip!

(I'm a night owl, and find myself at Bob's eating a freshly fried donut more than my cardiologist would approve--about 2 times a month, easily.)
author: jj w.

description:
ohhhh my tummy, save me.... 

I came in around 12:30 to a limited selection of donuts. I was really looking forward to either the apple fritter or a plain chocolate iced donut, which they had NEITHER!@@#@#!(*!)(*)!((!)# she said in about 45 minutes they would have some, but it was ok. If they had any on the shelf I might not have made a detour to El Farolito to kill those 45+ minutes. So upon arriving back 2 hours later I ended up getting both the apple fritter AND chocolate donut as well as an almond filled pastry for my friend... which basically ended up being half mine anyway (Yes, this is after stuffing myself with Mexican food beforehand as well).  In comparing Bob's with Kingpins I will have to give it to Kingpins by a small margin for their chocolate iced donuts. Kingpins just has more of a doughy inside with that nice semi crunch on the outside. When it comes to apple fritters there is no comparison. Bob's just has one of the biggest and doughiest apple fritters I have ever tasted. It is not at all greasy or sickenly sweet as most donut shops. In fact, neither of the donuts or pastry was greasy as most other donut places. Chalk this place down for another late night craving destination.
author: Steven T.

description:
yup I'm yelping on my sidekick, cuz I'm hardcore like that. anyway, they've got the recipe for success: food that's great and open late. and I've gotta admit, I do love me some donuts.

its amazing how they're so crisp on the outside yet so moist on the inside. I usually don't like cake donuts (they tend to be too dry) but these were nice and chewy. they also had these merengues that really looked like char siu baos, and I walked out craving some!

service was great and when I lamented the lack of cinnamon-sugar donuts, the lady ran in the back and grabbed me some. 'sides, where else can u go for donuts fresh outta the oven at 11pm?
author: Torie Y.

description: Call me crazy, but was feeling ambitious and had to do a Bobs vs. Donuts and Things, Coke vs Pepsi style glazed donut taste test.  It was close, but Donuts and things down the street edged out Bobs.  Donuts and Things was sweeter and lighter and just plain better.  However in terms of service, Bob's hands down.  The old man at Donuts and Things isn't he friendliest guy ive ever met.
author: Barry m.

description: It can be 1AM or 7AM. No doubt about it Bob's is there to fill your late night donut craving. Local rock stars and party people can be spotted here in the late hours.
author: Jennifer S.

description: You haven't lived until you've had a Bob's donut that just came straight out of the fryer. As good as their donuts are even when they weren't just made, if you're lucky enough to get there right as a fresh batch is coming out, your reward is a perfect piece of fried dough that will warm you to your core on a cold night.
author: Jon S.

description: Cake Crumb Doughnut= Yum. Once I witnesssed an intoxicated young man come in, and bitched how he was there again. His 6-pack pressed firmly against his tight-fitted green t-shirt tucked into his low rise jeans that had to be held on by a white didn't indicate he had any negative side effects. But then he stormed back in 5 minutes later, slapped $20 on the counter with the instructions that they were not to serve him the next night when he tried to come in after midnight. Where I am from, that's how you make a friend.
author: Jean W.

description: This is not the place for anyone to maintain their diet. Apple fritters....yummmmmm-o. Now for the entertainment...but give it a minute. go to illbilly.com and check out the Maximum Wage video featuring Bob's Donuts.
author: Sherie R.

description: Oh how you made me the happiest drunk girl in the land on Sunday! I marched out of the Cinch (in order to pick up cigs and hit the ATM-a twofer  if you will) and on my way back I spied with my little eye a tray of apple fritters coming straight out of the oven/rack thingy and steaming up the window!!!! I ran straight across the street and waited like a good person behind the eight or so other shnokered individuals eagerly anticipating the same delights. I purchased two of these little miracles and carried around my warm bag of pastry magic for the rest of the night, giddy on the excitement alone. Now tell me what in this world can make you so excited to just have the doughnuts that you in fact, don't eat it until the next day? Only a snack from Bob's at 1am  can induce this level of euphoria my friends!
author: Veronica G.

description: Their donuts are fabulous.  Sadly, there seem to be plenty of times when I want one and there are none available.  It seems to be a particular problem in the early evening hours.  I'm too old to be going out for donuts at 3 am.  Once they run out, they should start cooking up some more!
author: Squirrel L.

description: I love Bob's...although I must confess I only go there after 11 p.m. (that is when the donuts are freshly fried and hand dipped!)...sometimes I even make a point to stay up so that we can go to Bob's...also not a bad place to run and grab a quick snack if you are the Red Devil!
author: Alisa S.

description: HOT apple fritters at 1:00 am.  Melt in your mouth amazing.
author: Caitlin O.

description: OMG!!! Amazingly GOOD!! This is the best donut place in San Francisco!!! I try to go there whenever im near there. Place opens around 6 mayb 7 and closes til 10? anywho you should check this place out on your way to work, school? Or even after when u feel like eatting something sweet! good prices too!
author: Silvia C.

description: Best donuts in the city. When I used to live near Polk, this place was perfect. I would occasionally make a stop here after the bars closed just in time to get a fresh batch of apple fritters made in the middle of the night. My arteries are happy I moved out of the area, but I definitely am not.
author: charlie A.

description: OMG. Hot donuts at 1am to satisfy those drunken cravings. That sweet choc icing on a hot donut melting in your mouth and sliding down your throat like liquid gold. Sweet crumb donuts and crispy old fashioned ones or cinnamon treats. You want it, I know. And it tickles me to know that Bob's is open 24 hour.
author: Faye P.

description: Bob's can't be the best donut shop in the city.  Their donuts were not fresh (the woman said they were from 7 hours ago).  And she said they only bake some donuts on some days as the selection was sparse.  No apple fritters?  No maple bars?  What do you have?  I had a jelly filled and it was good 'cause they put jelly in between two halves like a bagel with cream cheese so you get more jelly than the normal jelly-filled.  Even Krispy Kremes (which I'm not into) has warm donuts and wide selection.  Even Happy Donuts had apple fritters at midnight on a Thursday!
author: kiwi l.

description: mmmm, donut. After running a marathon for some reason my friends and I were craving donuts so we yelped and found this place. The donuts were fresh, fluffy, and delicious. The place is very mom-n-pop and nothing fancy, and the donuts are cheap. The only thing is they should stick to the donuts, and x-nay on the croissants.
author: Jamie W.

description: Very cool donut shop that is located on Polk street between a variety of different bars. Parking is hard to find so be prepared to drive in circles. I got a dozen donut holes and two freshly glazed donuts with crumbs. It just tastes amazing when it comes out fresh, you can definitely taste the difference. I haven't tried the apple fritter here but maybe I'll luck out next time when I walk by this place again.
author: Dave Y.

description: HOT DONUTS! Why do you have to write anything else? I really don't want to hear about F. Scott Fitzgerald and I don't care if you've recently had a "debacle." Just shut up and eat another one.
author: Raina A.

description: Many a time have I spent drooling with my nose pressed up against the glass at Bob's Donuts, deciding what I should try this time around and trying really hard not to buy a whole dozen for myself.  The perfect place after a late night out, as the doughnuts will be fresh out of the vat and still nice and warm. And everyone who works here is always incredibly friendly... a huge plus in my book!
author: Nicole z.

description: Pretty tasty and they make them fresh and warm right there. The apple fritter could have had more apples but it was still good. 4 stars because they don't have blueberry jelly donuts. A prostitute came in there and she was early 20's and that was sad; but the warm box of donuts quickly turned my frown upside down. I don't know if they are warm all day long that would be nice though.
author: melissa h.

description:
Synopsis:
Donuts here are good, esp around midnight when they are fresh from the fryer and recently glazed.

The Scene:
Not too much to see hear, just Aya, a super nice Japanese woman who loves to talk to regulars. If you are out for a late night snack, and not for a sobering one, I would avoid this place - it can get really crowded.

The Food:
The Crumb Donuts are the best, hands down. Everything else is just kind of ordinary.

The Best Part:
If you time it correctly (around 12:30) you can get amazingly fresh donuts.
author: Franc S.

description: The absolute best place to get a chocolate old fashioned around 11 pm!  Cake doughnuts are simply the best at this hole in the wall.
author: Kenny Y.

description: Forget Krispy Kream. If you are up and about at 2:00a.m. and need some food, goto Bob's for a fresh from the fryer donut.  It is 10 times better.
author: Lams L.

description:
that one star is because i had to give it something and for taste alone the hot donuts are good.  BUT i used to go to BOB'S too many times a week. after dancing i'd get there about 1a when the 
hot  donuts were just done, couldn't beat it.
then i went there one day, pulled up into my
illegal space at the end of the bus stop and 
gathered my funds.  as i sat there i noticed the
lady outside wipping the windows down.  then 
she went in and came out with a spatula (that
looked mighty familiar as the donut scooper!) 
and started scraping between the window molding!!!!
i was agasht  and disgusted all at once.  i really was 
shocked.  i got hygene issues with people and food staff 
especcailly so this was unbeleivable.  so much so that i 
waited til she went it to confirm it was the same spatula
and sure enough she walked back in and layed it down 
next to the donuts!  i wish i had my video camera, i had been
out at an event and almost brought it that day.  so next time
you have a donut there, remember it  was most likely scooped
up at some point with a spatula that scraped polk st crudd.
author: misskim f.

description: This place as great. Had some time to spare before going to a show up the street so I headed over there and ordered a chocolate old fashioned and some donut holes. It was pushing 8pm and everything tasted like it had just been made. It was also really cheap. So great price, great donuts, great place to sit down and eat.
author: Zack L.

description: Let me say I don't really like donuts.  but  this place has the BEST jelly donut I have ever eaten.  I would like to be buried with one in hand.  Seriously, so much jelly (beyonce couldn't even handle it) and in such perfect harmony with the delicious pillowy donut.  YUM.
author: Kerry F.

description: Make a complete Nob Hill food adventure by going to Picadilly's for Fish n Chips, then walk across the street to get some fresh donuts at Bob's. So tempting...I dare you to walk past the window, see all the goodies, smell the fresh donut scent wafting out the door, and NOT walk in. Bet you can't do it!! :)
author: CHERiE Y.

description: Where else can you get delicious donuts and makeup tips from tranny hookers at 2 a.m.?
author: Rebecca H.

description: Bob's serves a good, honest donut at under a buck a piece. For this city, that's pretty good going. The store is open 24 hours too, so if you wake in the night with an uncontrollable urge, Bob's is there for you. In addition to the basics, they serve frosted donuts, fritters, strudels, puddings, and a range of other weighty desserts, but for me the plain and cinnamon donuts are the only way to go. I won't recommend their coffee though. You'd have to be on a serious bender to enjoy that bitter smelling brew. I'd go next door if I drank the stuff. OK, so you're a Bob's Donuts fan. But have you got the T-shirt? San Franciscans looking for extra style points in the snippy-hip calles of Barcelona wear the Bob's Donuts T-shirt. That's God's own truth. The one thing I don't get is the absence of police in Bob's Donuts. What's up with that?
author: Paul S.

description: Only been there twice, both times a little more than a little tipsy.  Started drooling at the site of the sugary thick glaze being hand poured over the fresh donuts.  Definitely get them fresh, but that is kind of a given with donuts right?  Hot oil = mo' beta than dry room temperature oil in almost every situation!  I have only ever purchased the ginormous glazed (a great snack for four).  Best when eaten with friends.  Guys, try to get some ladies to take a bite out of it at the same time as you if you can.  Good, clean, sugary innocent fun.  How dirty can it be when your drinking milks, right?
author: Paul W.

description: After dancing and drinking the night away, my friends were hungry & one of them recommended this place.  The croissant and donuts were all fresh (right out of the oven!) and the place is very quaint.  They open up till late hours to feed us owls :)
author: Tisha Y.

description: Seriously the best donuts I have ever had. Andrew was working and fresh old fashions were cooking and he was so nice and let me have my old fashioned freshly prepared any way I wanted it. I had it glazed and it was the best donut ever. I also had a sprinkled chocolate cake donut and it was amazing as well. If you are in the city you have to go here.
author: Sydni S.

description: Bob's has the biggest glazed donut I've ever seen, it's about 10 inches in diameter. It makes a great birthday donut. It's the perfect late night treat!
author: Brian B.

description:
saturday night. out crawling along polk street haunting the same joints that i usually do, when we pass by bobs.

well let me rephrase:

saturday night, stumbling along what i hope to be polk street after imbibing some spirited beverages at random bars when it hits me. that smell. like the lynard skynard song (which was fittingly about drugs and addiction) ooh that smell, cant you smell that smell? i mean seriously, it is hard to miss. one of my buddies tells the group that this place is world famous for its fritters.  

i am no mathematician but i will attempt to break down some simple math for you.

jason + fritters = not a wise or healthy decision

jason + drunk + fritters = best decision ever

i did not actually order a fritter for myself. i was somehow able to find a tad of self restraint that i thought i had lost after my fourth shot of straight vodka, warm, from a broken shot glass...

i stumbled over to a group of girls who were eating their various donuts. some chocolate and some fritters. i spark up a conversation.
imagine middle english mixed with a healthy dose of fantasmical charm. 

somehow, some way, one of the girls allows me to share her donuts with her (maybe it was because she was merely taking bites of the donut and then spitting it out in her napkin so as to not take on the calories). holy hell they were delicious! the chocolate was amaaazing. so fluffy and yet crispy on the outside. the chocolate was rich and put to shame so many other chocolate toppings at donut shops around sf.  the fritter was life altering. in that you will undoubtedly alter your life span in the negative after munching down on it. but also in the "i have never and will never again have a fritter this good in my life".

although i am not a huge sweets person i have to give props to bobs. i definitely understand why his donuts are world famous. they are delicious and if you are anywhere near polk street and you like tasty fried dough you need to find yourself at bobs.
author: Jason B.

description: I honestly never really thought I liked donuts. I know it sounds crazy, but I just never thought they tasted that great. That was until a friend brought me to Bob's at the magic time when they are being made and are still warm. I had a warm old fashioned and it was amazing. The apple fritters are pretty fantastic as well.
author: Rose K.

description:
Bob's will forever hold a place in my heart.  The French-style donuts are so light and delicious and the prices are right!  The people who work behind the counter are always kind and help you fulfill your sugar cravings with aplomb because they sure know their stuff!

The only reason I'm not giving them a five-star rating is that I tried a berry pastry once and was disappointed.  I promise you though, stick to the donuts and you will be one happy camper.
author: Sarah H.

description: B-o-b-apostrophe...s!  I end up at Bob's donughts approximately 3 nights a week--oftentimes on the way home from a night at the Buc and always with much excitement.  The donughts here are out of this world!!!  Go late at night (it's open all night) and just ask for whatever is fresh.  And get a croissant.  If the apple fritters are hot off the grill prepare to have your mind blown.  If you're feeling especially adventurous, be sure to request a liferaft (donut 8 inches in diameter).  Perhaps you'll be lucky enough to get a fresh maple donut WITH...wait for it...RAINBOW SPRINKLES!  Just don't get the cookies, they aren't that good.
author: Brian D.

description: So GOoooood!  Shady part of the neighborhood.  Polk creeps me out a little, but otherwise, this place is RAD.  Cash only, which is a bummer.  After dinner, go to Bob's for some donuts.
author: Olivia S.

description: I'm drooling.  Donuts the size of my head.  Im in heaven.  I love the classic coffee counter setting.  An authentic donut shop.  Plain and simple.
author: Alexis M.

description: OMG I don't think it gets much better than stumbling home up Polk St. from the Hemlock and getting a hot out of the fryer apple donut from Bob's.  Also my boyfriend is obsessed with the old timey quarter baseball game.  If you are bored you can always pull up a stool and watch a blurry crime drama or infomercial with one of Polk Street's colorful late night dwellers.
author: Katie M.

description:
chocolate croissant yumminess! 

these croissants are HUGEmongous ... at first , i split one in half, thinking i'd be good ... but i just went back for the second half. 

guilt guilt guilt guilt guilt ....
author: cynthia q.

description: Oh Em GeE. Three words or letters whatever you call it, mmm mmm mmm.  So delish, cheap, accessible, and old-fashioned. Definately has that old fashion sf charm that we so dearly cherish. Just walked in picked up a few and now im on here bc i love it that much. The christmas cookies are delish!!! Go and indulge on DONUTS!! yes!!!
author: Tiffany d.

description: Sweet afternoon delights. Or midnight delights. Yes, anytime, really. This and a tall drink of skim milk, and I think I might be able to forgo the opposite sex!
author: Wing L.

description: Bob's knows that after a night on Polk street, the best way to end the evening is with a hot fresh donut. OPEN 24 HOURS!! Can you believe it? You don't need to know what's what, just ask for their freshest donut and you will surely be satisfied with the hot pastry that enters your mouth. The Apple fritters here are to die for, and I am not usually a fan (often too dry and crusty, but the moistness of this one, my god!). I've had guests from other countries spend all their food money at Bob's. It truly is the American dream.
author: Sonya D.

description: Mother of God! There is this guy i work with named  John who is crazy about donuts.  he brought in a whole array for us, and i got to try every single one.  i don't think it's just because i hadn't had a donut for years, but i was smitten. they were sooooo delicious.  apparently, i have to go in for the huge apple fritter. ahhhh, how wonderful to have a huge apple fritter in my line-up.
author: sarah C.

description:
I totally don't eat donuts (go with it), so I've never tried any of Bob's dainties (unless you count the apple fritters and jelly rolls my friends have bought, which I've sampled, just a bit, when they've been momentarily distracted).  But if I were to try them, I'm sure they'd be worthy of five stars--based only on their aroma--doughy and toothsome--of course.

I have purchased Bob's meringues, and advise you not to bother: they're stale-ish, and not very sweet, and you might as well treat yourself to a real pastry.
author: Hannah J.

description: This polk street gem makes some of the best donuts in the world. The secret is going after midnight when they are making the donuts. They proudly display their confecctions in the window, but the key is to get the ones from the counter, still warm. There is nothing better than a donut fresh from the oil hand dipped into your choice of chocolate, maple or honey glaze. On my last visit I went all out for the whole dozen. I was expecting to pay over ten bucks, but was set aback by the six dollar price, amazing. The only conclusion I can come to is with such close proximity to the TL there must be some sort of crack or crystal meth in these things. YUM!!!!!!!
author: mike m.

description: Donuts, made from scratch - 24 hours a day. As God intended. The apple fritter and crumble donut are the best anywhere. I'm glad I don't  have to walk by here everyday.
author: Brian C.

description: Their donuts I think are alright. I like that it is always open but I seriously have had better Donuts. We did a Polk Street Bar/Food Crawl last week and it ended early mainly because of this place. My friend had a donut from there and we went to a restaurant next door. This was the last thing he ate and he went to the bathroom and eventually collapsed. He then had to go to ER (true story). After going to ER we found out he had Major Constipation. We don't know the exact reason that led him to collpase but in my opinion Bob's donuts had something to do with it.
author: Nir B.

description: I honestly didn't see what the big deal was. Apple Fritter was just what I expected, nothing more nothing less--good but not so good that I'm gonna rave about it like the rest of these reviews just because I can get one at 3AM.
author: Krystha B.

description: Bob's Donuts are the platonic ideal of donuts. They taste like donuts should taste - even better than your memories of really good donuts.
author: Timothy O.

description: We had a donut-themed wedding shower for a co-worker yesterday morning so got donuts from Bob's.  I'm a moderate donut fan, but I'm cutting down on the excess food so I only ate one.  I must say though, that was one good donut!  It wasn't very heavy at all so I felt like I could've eaten a couple more (but I didn't).
author: Kris L.

description: Might be the best donuts i've had, although i have to come here late night for the fresh donuts, i really have to.  If they taste this good cold, hot must be heaven
author: Herbert S.

description: Best apple fritters in the world.  I love coming here on Saturday mornings for a nice fritter, latte and cigarette.  I also recently organized a donut sale at work to raise money for a charity and they sold like hotcakes - more quickly than when I did a Krispy Kreme sale.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Personally, I feel that cheese (meaning nachos, pizza, or cheese fries) is the ideal fuel for herding gin-soaked, belligerently drunk friends down Polk Street, and so I have not experienced the late night sugar rush of Bob's 2am fritters.  I can, however, attest to the fact that they are the best doughnuts anywhere, even while sober. This place is too close to my house.  Luckily, so is Gorilla.
author: Amanda B.

description: In my day, dunkin donuts was the definition of, well, donuts.   Luckily, i happen to move in 1/2 a block from Bob's Donuts.   Its changed my whole outlook on the circular delights, in a Homer Simpson-esq way.     Make your way through the random homeless that sit in there for the coffee, and have a seat the counter.   Fresh donuts begin at about 11:30pm, and the circle of life begins.    Watch as the age old machine cranks out rings of dough into the vat of life giving oil.   Out they come, in various shapes and flavors, and into the vat o' glaze.  Resist the drunken temptation to dunk your head into said vat, as it will ensure your hurried exit from the premises.   Instead, feast on the many donut choices and enjoy the latest features on the 13" TV.     Dare not mention the donut place who's initials are K.K.
author: Dan G.

description: It's been a long night watching a marathon of To Catch a Predator with Chris Hansen on MSNBC and after watching all these sweaty perverts get pwned by Chris Hansen, I got a little hungry. I could of went to a thai joint for some quick Duck fried Rice, but I was in the mood for donuts, and just any normal donuts. I wanted Donuts from Bob's on Polk Street. It's the only place I can think of where I can get a giant donut for only 3.50! My absolute favorite is the French Donut, but when you think about it, no one can fuck up a French Donut, NO ONE!
author: Harry B.

description: Have never understood why people like Krispy Kremes.....they are so sweet, they make my teeth ache.  Bob's cake doughnuts are close to perfect, though.  Just sweet enough, nice "bite", and perfect glazes.  The older Asian woman at the counter is always friendly, and genuinely interested in her customers.
author: Norman R.

description: I tried to buy donuts here a couple times before I actually succeeded.  Go at night, like after 10pm or later... When we went during the day there was an older man behind the register who didn't even look up and no prices or anything and the stuff didn't look too fresh.  At night there was a friendly young lady who was very helpful and even went out of her way to make sure we had the freshest donuts.  Not the best donuts I've ever had, but good.  We got some old fashioned, coffee-cake like ones (not sure what they were), chocolate iced with sprinkles, and maple iced.  Cost $6 for a dozen with a tip.  The fact that there are no prices still freaks me out.   I'd go again... at night.
author: Green T.

description: My fiancee ate a whole dozen Bob's donuts and crullers in less than two days, and I love her all the more for it.
author: David Y.

description: If I was working late on a school project and I need a little pick-me-up, I'd walk over to Bob's for my sugar fix. A couple of donuts or an apple fritter, two milks or a water and I was all set.
author: Michael R.

description: Bob's made an appearance several times before at weekly Donut Wednesday at work, and consistently won cheery compliments... mind you, from a sober morning-fresh tasting panel, which I'd consider a reasonable baseline.  But then there was last Friday night after the Big Foot.  Yes, the crowd was rowdy, but rightfully so: steaming fresh donuts were parading out of the fryer.  Friends, those hot apple fritters don't make you feel the slightest guilt for a shameless feed fest right before bed.  They make you feel guilty for not having more.
author: MScott S.

description: Where is that sugary smell coming from? I could smell the sugar from a block away. My friend and I followed that scent like bloodhounds and were rewarded by hot fresh donuts. Yum, I work out so I can eat this and tons of ice-cream. Plus, they sell milk to go with the donuts.
author: Amy Y.

description: I remember going to this donut shop a little over 10 years ago when me and my friends would go out dancing at a nearby club. The donuts were freshly made and they were devilishly delicious. Last night, I paid homage to this donut shop and got myself a donut. It was pure fat and sugar but it was still the way I remembered it to be -- devilishly delicious!
author: Chad B.

description: Affordable and delicious! Great when I'm missing Paris and craving a croissant!
author: Rebecca P.

description: Five stars for the window display alone.  It is nothing short of torture to stand outside of Bob's late at night waiting for a bus, drooling for one of those glistening morsels of deep fried deliciousness.
author: Mr. G.

description: Pure Deliciousness. Nice Counterpeople. Did I mention delicious?
author: Fred L.

description: This place is GREAT.  I still haven't gone to the actual shop, but my friend bought me these 2 nights in a row.  It's one of those things that you can't put down late at night and you try to take just a few bites but before you know it you've eaten 4 donuts. The apple fritter was one of the best I've ever had and the buttermilk donut is amazing as well. Order your giant donuts ahead of time if you want them...I need to get that soon.
author: Joe T.

description: I dream of Bob's.  Literally.  Especially their cake donuts with chocolate icing.  If you go late at night (1+ am) they are hot and have a delightfully delicate crumb.  In fact, get two.  You'll thank yourself in the morning.
author: Zoe V.

description: I miss just walking down there whenever I want to get a maple old-fashion. But the treat is the "Apple Thing"...that long baked treat that looks like an Apple cake-bread thing...I get it all the time, but still can't remember the name of it. Hard not to stop when driving by and seeing an open parking spot.
author: Terry O.

description: Mmmmmm. Yummy! Best place to stop after Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Jo M.

description:
Bob's Donuts is F*#$ing amazing.  While growing up I moved coast to coast and from South to North(both coasts) and tasted a wide variety of donut styles from Winchil's and Dunkin' Donuts to Crispy Creme and all the mom and pop shops in between.  I will confidently say that Bob's donuts is hands down the best our nation has to offer.

They Start Frying at 2am in time for last call and the place fills up with drunk people until past 3am but they don't stop frying until 7am.  The Donuts are best when they're still warm and they have an amazing selection if you're there at the right time (3 - 7AM).

Everything I've had here is good, everything I had hot was better.  The apple Fritter is on 7x7's "100 to try before you die" SF list... It's good but whatever is hot at the moment is better.

I've seen people complain about a "weak" selection, not true, but they're often sold out by noon.

They're open 24/7/365
author: Frank S.

description: Stepping out of the nearby Sushi Rock late one night, we couldn't help but notice this heart warming sweet buttery scent...and followed our noses.... to Bob's Donuts!!! Altho we were skeptical at first, reading the reviews taped to the walls had us convinced. Cheap, yuummyyyy, steamy, sticky donuts late night...is just what the doctor ordered.
author: Sofia J.

description: The bestest, freshest, most sinful donuts in the city!  This is the original donut, not that light/airy donut you get at  Krispy Kreme.  One of  these will stick for a while!  I only allow myself one a year... :-)
author: anne m.

description: Randomly walking by Bobs when I smell what can only be freshly made doughnuts...Bobs is now my favorite doughnut in town...and super cheap!
author: Patrick M.

description: This place is awesome! I would rather have a Bob's Donut than a KK. Coming home late at night feeling groovy from libations, don't forget to stop at Bob's for a real night cap - haha. I've been in bed watching a movie on a rainy night and rallied down there for some fresh (made consistently around 10pm+) treats. If you know me, that says quite a bit ;-).
author: Mike C.

description:
Average at best.  Yelpers must be really drunk when they eat these to give them 5 stars.  Cause I went today, and although the donuts were made fresh this morning, they were greasy and really just....average.  Also, they gave me a stomachache, and I only ate one.

Sorry Bob, nothing special here, compared to say, Tartine.  

Also, most annoying service.  I went in, only 1 other customer there.  I sat down at the counter and was literally ignored.  Only when another customer walked in off the street and ordered while I was waiting did I realize I was supposed to order up front, THEN sit at the counter.  Sheesh, couldn't the lady at least tell me that and then not ignore me?

Coffee was decent, nothing special but not horrible either and at least they had some half and half out.  I gave the other donut to my boyfriend.  Considering that will stab him with a fork if he tried to touch one of my Tartine morning buns, that's a sign I probably won't be going back.
author: Mel B.

description:
I don't even like donuts...but Bob's won me over...

Service...good...

Price....good....

Donuts.... a whole another level

I think I've died and went to donut heaven
author: Mary L.

description: best place to get donuts...late night or early morning! cake donuts are awesome!!!
author: Kristy R.

description: Donuts...mmmmmmmm. I've heard tell that Bobs isn't the cleanest place to get your grub, but there's a reason places are called 'greasy spoon'.  Best donuts in town!
author: Colleen B.

description: I have a serious weekness for donuts.  It seems to be genetic, my 65 yr old pops still starts every day with a chocolate donut.  Anyway, these are some good-ass donuts.  I recommend a simple cinnamon donut.  The apple fritters are darn good as well.
author: John R.
